awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Coherent Manipulation and Transfer of Quantum Information amongst Single Spin Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
****Technical Abstract****
The emerging area of "quantum information science" has seen rapid advances in exploiting the coherent control of single spins in defect centers in diamond and SiC, opening up a new pathway toward qubits that function at room temperature. This proposal aims to extend these remarkable developments toward the coherent manipulation and full state transfer of quantum information in heterogeneous systems built from disparate materials whose individual quantum properties are already well understood. The ultimate goal is to achieve quantum-coherent communication between physically distinct quantum systems at the single spin level and at room temperature. The PIs will combine spatio-temporally resolved single spin spectroscopies with the design and fabrication of model systems that couple single spins (such as defects in SiC) with ensemble spins in low dimensional communication channels (such as 2DEGs and nanowires). The proposed research offers advanced technical training in quantum materials and measurement and provides ideal training for future careers in academics and industry. The PIs will also enhance the diversity and excellence of undergraduate research through institutional programs and by collaboratively teaching a cross-disciplinary undergraduate course on the Practice of Science.

****Non-Technical Abstract***
Modern information technology relies on devices such as lasers, flash memory and magnetic tunnel junctions that exploit the quantum mechanical aspects of the natural world. Such device technologies still do not make use of the full technological potential of quantum mechanics, restricting their functionality to control over the amplitude of quantum mechanical waves and ignoring their phase. The emerging area of "quantum information science" seeks to redress this limitation by exploring the technological possibilities of the more non-intuitive aspects of quantum mechanics, namely quantum coherence and quantum entanglement. A key challenge for quantum information processing is the development of pragmatic scenarios that will allow the exchange of coherent quantum information between disparate parts of a system. This proposal aims to demonstrate such phenomena in heterogeneous systems built from disparate materials whose individual quantum properties are well understood. The ultimate goal is to achieve quantum-coherent communication between physically distinct quantum systems at the single spin level and at room temperature. The proposed research offers advanced technical training in quantum materials and measurement and provides ideal training for future careers in academia and in industry. The PIs will also enhance the diversity and excellence of undergraduate research through institutional programs and by collaboratively teaching a cross-disciplinary undergraduate course on the Practice of Science.

por.por_cntn:
Much of modern information technology relies on the control of the wave-like behavior of electrons in nanoscale devices wherein some relevant dimensions are on the order of 10-100 nanometers. Examples include the reading sensors for magnetic memory that exploit ultra thin oxide "tunnel barriers" sandwiched by magnetic thin films and light emitting diodes/lasers that rely on the resonant modes of electron waves in nanoscale quantum wells and quantum dots. Such quantum devices have led to the first quantum revolution built upon the design and engineering the amplitude of quantum mechanical wave functions. Now, a second quantum revolution is brewing, one that depends of full control of the quantum mechanical wave function, both amplitude and phase. Just as silicon, gallium arsenide, gallium nitride, and ferromagnetic films formed the foundations for the first quantum revolution, the second quantum revolution will require the development of appropriate quantum materials that can serve as platforms for emerging quantum technologies. An important aspect of these new quantum materials is the identification of quantum states that can retain their phase for sufficient time to be usefully manipulated. This collaborative proposal between PIs at Penn State (Samarth) and Chicago (Awschalom) focused on combining disparate materials wherein the electron "spin" is the key quantum degree of freedom of interest. We investigated a variety of quantum materials wherein spin plays a central role in the physical behavior, ranging from topological surface states to nitrogen vacancy (NV) defects in diamond.     

Topological insulators are a class of quantum material wherein the combination of fundamental symmetry, quantum mechanics, and relativistic physics results in the special behavior of electrons on the surface: electrons moving in different directions have a natural direction of their spin. Designing quantum devices that exploit this property requires spatial control over time-reversal symmetry and chemical potential (energy). We demonstrated the ability to use all optical methods for writing and erasing micrometer scale quantum circuits whose behavior is determined by the local orientation of magnetization (which breaks time-reversal symmetry) and chemical potential (electron kinetic energy) in hybrid materials that combine ultra thin topological films with an oxide (SrTiO3) substrate. This collaborative work between Samarth and Awschalom groups was published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Science. Further, we also demonstrated that circularly polarized light could control the flow of spin and charge current in topological insulator thin films by varying the incidence angle of the exciting light, its wavelength, and an external voltage. The insights we obtained are important for engineering "opto-spintronic" devices that might become important components of quantum circuits. This collaborative work was published in Nature Communications. 

We also developed a new approach for manipulating spin-dependent defect states in diamond. In particular, we showed how a straightforward continuous wave protocol that takes advantage of the dipolar coupling between optically "bright" NV defects and optically "dark" P1 centers in diamond can be used to detect and polarize the dark P1 spins that are not directly accessible using optical excitation. By combining mutual spin flip transitions with radio frequency driving, we demonstrated the simultaneous optical polarization and detection of the electron spin resonance of the P1 center. This technique should be applicable to detecting and manipulating a broad range of dark spin populations that couple to the nitrogen vacancy center via dipolar fields, allowing for quantum metrology using these spin populations. This was published in Physical Review B. 

The broader impacts of this NSF grant were primarily in the training of personnel at Penn State in technically sophisticated areas of science and technology. This NSF grant provided primary support for a PhD student whose thesis focused on spin spectroscopy of NV centers in diamond and partial support for a second (female) PhD student whose thesis focused on opto-electronic studies of topological insulator heterostructure. After graduation, both students joined leading high tech companies in the US (Cree and Lam Research). The NSF grant also supported two undergraduate students who are still completing their degrees; one of them is from an under-represented group. Finally, the grant provided partial support for a postdoctoral scholar who is now employed as a research scientist in a staff position at an NSF-funded user facility (Materials Innovation Platform) at Penn State.
